awd_titl_txt: Collaboratice Research: Eliciting and Assessing Process Skills in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
In response to the national need to improve undergraduate STEM education, many instructors have implemented engaged student learning strategies into their courses.  These pedagogies involve the development of students? process skills, such as communication, teamwork, critical thinking, and problem solving, as students learn STEM content.  Because most STEM instructors have little training in how to assess student performance in these areas, the goal of this EHR: IUSE project will be to create resources that can be readily adopted to assess student process skills in a wide range of classroom types and across STEM disciplines.  A secondary goal will be to create professional development tools to improve the recognition and assessment of process skills by instructors and administrators at academic institutions.

Assessment is critical to improvement of student learning in STEM courses because it provides a measure of achievement and facilitates learning.  The types of assessment used by instructors telegraph to students what is valued in a course.  In order to better align engaged instructional methods and assessment this project will result in the development and evaluation of (a) a set of student interaction rubrics to assess evidence of process skills in active learning classroom environments, (b) a set of student product rubrics to assess evidence of process skills in student written work, and (c) an implementation guide to assist instructors in identifying and designing tasks that elicit evidence of process skill development and to facilitate the effective implementation of the rubrics.  Formative and summative evaluation questions will be addressed through ongoing assessment and revision of the rubrics; a process that will also establish their validity, reliability, and utility.  Oral and written feedback will be obtained from faculty participants.  They will also provide input on the usability of the implementation guidebook throughout its development.  The propagation of the rubrics and implementation guide will occur through the POGIL network.  The two workshops will be part of the six, annual POGIL regional meeting agendas.  Results of this work will be submitted to the Journal of College Science Teaching.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this collaborative project was to create resources that can be readily adopted by instructors to assess student process skills (also known as transferable or professional skills) in a wide range of classrooms and across STEM disciplines. Transferable skills addressed by this project include interpersonal communication, teamwork, information processing, and critical thinking, problem solving, management, metacognition, and written communication. This was accomplished by:

  1. Creating a set of rubrics to assess evidence of interpersonal and cognitive skills in student written work and interactions in active learning environments.

  2. Creating implementation materials to assist instructors in identifying and developing tasks that elicit evidence of transferable skill development, and to facilitate the effective implementation of the rubrics.

  3. Creating and facilitating a series of faculty development workshops to aid instructors in adopting and implementing the rubrics. 

Intellectual Merit: A key outcome was the development and validation of rubrics centered on transferable skills (e.g.  interpersonal communication, teamwork, information processing, critical thinking) for instructors to provide assessment strategies for formative and evaluative purposes. In particular, we transitioned from developing traditional analytic rubrics to designing an innovative feedback-style rubric. The feedback rubrics are designed to make explicit to students and instructors the observable behaviors that comprise the transferable skills, and then to further offer tangible suggestions for student improvement of these skills. The use of the ELIPSS rubrics have been proven effective in providing feedback to students and informing instructors as to the effectiveness of their instructional strategies in supporting the development of process skills. Implementation of the rubrics has resulted in changes to instructor practice and to improvements in student skills as well as the operationalization of the skills themselves in the context of a variety of STEM disciplines .

We also identified a framework to a stepwise development of transferable skills along two dimensions, cognitive and interpersonal, rather than focusing on the context in which rubrics would be applied (student written work vs observable student interactions). Implementation materials such as videos from practitioners in a variety of STEM settings using the materials in novel ways are available, along with an instructor?s guide that further details implementation strategies. Faculty workshops designed to introduce faculty to the assessment of process skills via these rubrics were facilitated at a wide range of venues, and received overwhelmingly positive reviews.  These workshops (and the supporting ELIPSS website) resulted in a significant number of adoptions within and well beyond the POGIL community, across STEM disciplines.  

Broader Impacts: This project was designed to use strategies that have been shown to be effective in supporting propagation of educational innovations. We intentionally designed the rubrics to be used in a variety of STEM disciplines and with students at different academic levels, engaging a core team of faculty from a range of disciplines and institutional settings to provide feedback on the design and implementation of the rubrics. The rubrics are also deliberately positioned to work in any active learning environment rather than being tailored to a specific pedagogical approach. We have designed and delivered multiple workshops customized to different audiences, given 59 presentations at a variety of venues, and published five peer-reviewed manuscripts related to the work of the project. Over the course of the project, over 700 instructors have participated in project workshops, and additional instructors have been introduced to the materials through the POGIL Project workshops and other related faculty development workshops.

To sustain continued adoption, the ELIPSS project website (www.ELIPSS.com) was designed to be user-friendly and engaging to bring new users into the project and provide them with easy access to classroom resources (in a variety of print forms) and strategies. To date, over 800 accounts were created at the project website to access resources prior to removing the registration barrier, and over 3300 visits have since been made to the website. In the recent year, an updated website with an easier registration protocol has attracted over 500 users; this increase comes despite the minimal number of workshops and presentations we were able to offer during that time frame. The rubrics have been used by numerous instructors from a range of disciplines and institutional types, impacting thousands of students. It is likely the case that these instructional materials are moving past the early adopters stage into more mainstream usage, and are transitioning into being considered standard tools readily employed by STEM faculty.
